description: UMD 1.8 is the tenth release of UMD-1 (Unified Middleware Distribution) made available for the EGI production infrastructure. &nbsp;This release provides security updates from Technology Providers.
releaseNotes: <div>This release contains the following products:</div><br/><div>EMI Technology Provider:</div><br/><div>Job Execution services:</div><div>CREAM 1.13.4 release: This release includes two important updates in the &nbsp;cream sub-components BLAH and gLite-gsoap/gss.</div><div><ul><li>BLAH 1.16.6 update, &nbsp;fixes the problem of the bupdater for LSF which can leave job in IDLE state due to a timestamp problem.<br></li><li>gLite-gsoap/gss 3.0.3 update, &nbsp;fix a bug of the plugin by fixing buffer under-run during setting proxy filename. Remember that GSS module should be updated when globus-gssapi-gsi &gt;= 10.6 (globus &gt;= 5.2.1) is used.</li></ul></div><div>Storage Management:</div><div>StoRM 1.8.3 &nbsp;release : This release solve the issue of read permission acl to others on configuration file and on the &nbsp;yaim-storm on which storage area roots does not belong to storm user.</div><br/><div>Globus platform (Provided by IGE):</div><br/><div>File Transfer and File Access:</div><div>Globus GRIDFTP 5.2.1:</div><div><ul><li>On this new release of gridftp among several bug fixes, provided support for default disk and network stacks: globus-gridftp-server options -dc-default and -fs-default. It is also added server support for setting file modification time and added ability (MLSC) to stream directory listings over the control channel.<br></li></ul></div><br/>

products.name: egi.umd-release
products.releaseNotes:
This package includes the Unified Middleware Distribution (UMD) release file and the needed repository configuration.

Includes repository definition for:
- EGI-trustanchors repository
- UMD-1 base repository
- UMD-1 updates repository

Additionally it requires the existence of the EPEL repository definition which could be provided by an OS package or from EPEL itself.

Finally it installs and configures yum-priorities according to UMD requirements.

Installation Guide:
Distribution specific installation guide:
Scientific Linux: Tested on "Scientific Linux SL release 5.6 (Boron)"
- Installing the umd-release RPM adds all missing repositories that are needed for the installation of UMD products.

Centos: Tested on "CentOS release 5.6 (Final)"
- OS repositories do NOT provide definitions of EPEL repository. Centos users have to first install the latest epel-release package that can be found at:
http://download.fedora.redhat.com/pub/epel/5/i386/repoview/epel-release.html
- OS repositories do NOT provide an package that fulfills the "jdk" requirement (found in some UMD products). Due licensing issues this has to be done manual. For more info see:
http://wiki.centos.org/HowTos/JavaOnCentOS
- Installing the umd-release RPM adds all other repositories that are needed for the installation of UMD products.

Scientific Linux CERN: Tested on "Scientific Linux CERN SLC release 5.6 (Boron)"
- This distribution is intended only for people IN CERN. An additional repository "cernonly", which is only available in the CERN intranet, has to be enabled to provide a package that fulfills the "jdk" requirement. Otherwise Centos guidelines could apply here too.
- Installing the umd-release RPM adds all other repositories that are needed for the installation of UMD products.

products.name: emi.cream
products.description:
The CREAM (Computing Resource Execution And Management) Service is a simple, lightweight service for job management operation at the Computing Element (CE) level.



CREAM accepts job submission requests (which are described with the same JDL language used to describe the jobs submitted to the Workload Management System) and other job management requests (e.g. job cancellation, job monitoring, etc).



CREAM can be used by the Workload Management System (WMS), via the ICE service, or by a generic client, e.g. an end-user willing to directly submit jobs to a CREAM CE. For the latter user case a C++ command line interface and Java clients are available.



CREAM exposes a web service interface.

products.name: emi.storm
products.description:
StoRM (STOrage Resource Manager) is a:



    light

    scalable

    flexible

    high-performance

    file system independent



storage manager service (SRM) for generic disk based storage system, compliant with the standard SRM interface version 2.2. StoRM provides data management capabilities in a Grid environment to share, access and transfer data among heterogeneous and geographically distributed data centres.In particular, StoRM works on each POSIX filesystems (ext3, ext4, xfs, basically on everything than can be mounted on a Linux machine) but it also brings in Grid the advantages of high performance storage systems based on cluster file system ( such as GPFS from IBM or Lustre from Sun Microsystems ) supporting direct access (native POSIX I/O call) to shared files and directories, as well as other standard Grid access protocols. StoRM is adopted in the context of WLCG computational Grid framework.

products.name: ige.globus-gridftp
products.description: The GridFTP server and clients from the Globus Toolkit
products.changeLog: Based on Globus Toolkit 5.2.1. The 2.1.1 release contains an update of the globus-gridftp-server and globus-gridftp-server-control packages that addresses a security issue that could lead to wrong user mapping in the Globus GridFTP server in the presence of a malformed gridmap-file (Globus Jira GT-195, EGI RT #3765). In addition it introduces a feature to the globus-ftp-client package, previously available in the old VDT Globus distribution, that allows gridftp version 2 to be activated using environment variables (GGUS #81230).
